div.p:
I do not delay a moment to send my warmest
and best congratulations upon the very happy event which is
about to take place in your family and to assure that you
do me but common justice in supposing that I take the war
-mest warmest interest in whatever concerns my young friends - All
Abbots
ford Abbotsford
to an acre of Poyais Poyais was a fictional Central American territory described by Scottish general Gregor MacGregor. MacGregor recruited hundreds to invest in fake "Poyaisian" government bonds and land certificates while others migrated there and only found a jungle where more than half eventually died. MacGregor's scheme lasted from 1821 to 1837, so Scott here is writing about it right around the same time as the scheme was happening. that she will make an excellent
wife and more truly happy am I to think that she has
such an admirable prospect of matrimonial happiness al-
though although at the expence expense of thwarting the maxim & shewing showing
that

The course of true love sometimes may run smooth Here, Scott is playing on a quote from William Shakespeare's
A Midsummer Night's Dream.
It will make a pretty vista as I hope and trust for you my
good friend to look forwards with an increase of interest to fu-
turity futurity . Lady Scott Anne and Sophia send their sincere &
hearty congratulations upon this joyful occasion I hope to
hear her sing the petticoat of red some day someday in her own house,
I should be apt to pity you a little amid all your happi-
ness happiness if you had not besides other young companions
whose merits are only known to me by report my young
friend Miss Harriet This is likely referring to Harriet Douglas Cruger who, in the 1820s, stayed with Walter Scott at Abbotsford House. to prevent your feeling so much as
you would otherwise, the blank which this event might
occasion in your domestic society.

Sophia I hope will be soon able to make her con
gratulations congratulations She is recovering very well and overjoyed to

hear such good news from your quarter. I have been on a
short trip to Abbotsford to set painters &c to work to complete
what Slender would call "mine own great chamber" and on
my return I was quite delighted to see the change on my
daughter Little Johnie Hugh is likewise much better but will
require nursing & care for some years at least Yet I have often
known such hot-house plants bear the open air as well as
those who were bred
reard reared
on the open moor.

I am not at all surprized surprised at what you say of the Yankees
they are a people possessed of very considerable energy quickened
and brought into eager action by an honourable honorable love of their
country and pride in their institutions but they are as yet
rude in their ideas of social intercourse and totally ignorant
speaking generally of all the evil of good breeding which consists
chiefly in a postponement of ones own petty wishes or comforts
to those of others. By rude questions free and unfeeling observations
an absolute disrespect to other peoples feelings and a ready in
dulgence of their own they make one feverish in their company
though perhaps you may be ashamed to confess the reason.
But this will wear off and is wearing away here when they
have once got benches will soon fall into the use of cushions
They are advancing in the Arts & in literature and they will
not be long deficient in the petite morale especially as they
have like ourselves the rage for travelling - I have seen a
new work - the Pilot - by the author of the Spy & Pioneer - You know
is the celebrated Paul Jones - who I well remember advancing
above the island with three small vessels to lay Leith under
contribution - I remember my mother being alarmed with
the drum which she had heard all her life at 8 o'clock
conceiving it to be the pirates who had landed - I never saw

such a change as betwixt that time & 1797 in the military
state of a city then Edinburgh had scarce three companies of
men under arms and latterly she furnished 5000 with
complete appointments of cavalry artillery & infantry enough
to have eat Paul Jones and his whole equipage - Nay the very
square in which my father's house stands could then have
furnished a body of armed men sufficient to have headed back
as large a party as he could well have landed - However -
the Novel is a very clever one and the sea scenes & characters
in particular are admirably drawn; and I advise you to
read it as soon as possible

I have little news to send from Abbotsford
Spice is much better though still asthmatic. She
is extremely active and in high spirits though
most miserable long-backed
creature I ever saw - She is exactly
shadow of a dog on the wall
a sketch as a child makes
in its first attempt at drawing a
monster with a large head four feet and

a most portentous longitude of back. There was great propriety
in Miss Harriets dream after all for if ever a dog needed six
legs poor Spice certainly requires a pair of additional suppor
-ters supporters . She is now following me a little though the duty of body guard bodyguard
has devolved for the present on a cousin of hers a fierce game - devil
that goes at every thing and has cowed power Ourisk's courage in
a most extraordinary degree to Lady Scotts great vexation;

Here is a tale of dogs and dreams and former days but the only
pleasure in writing is to write whatever comes readiest to the pen.

My wife and Anne send kindest compliments of congratulation
as also Charles who has come down to spend four or five months
with us just enterd entered at Brazen Nose - on fire to be a scholar
of classical distinction and studying (I hope this however
will last like a very dragon.
div.closer:
Always my dear Miss Edge
worth Edgeworth
with best love to the Bride Though not explicitly named, we know this is referring to Sophia Edgeworth, who married Barry Fox in 1824. & to dear Harriet very much
yours
Walter Scott
Edinr 24 February
1824
